concept.label: 2017 video game
concept.definition:
"2017 video game" (noun):

1. A digital or electronic game that was first released or made available to the public in the calendar year 2017. This could encompass multiple platforms such as consoles, personal computers, or mobile devices.

2. These games often involve interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on two- or three-dimensional video display devices. They can belong to a wide range of genres, including but not limited to action, adventure, strategy, puzzle, role-playing, sports, and simulation.

3. The term "2017 video game" specifically relates to the year of release and does not necessarily denote any particular style, quality, or technological advancement in the field of video gaming. 

Note: This term is often used in the context of discussing developments and trends in the video game industry, or when comparing games from different time periods.

data.label: Our World is Ended
data.description: "Our World is Ended" is a video game developed in Japan and set in the year 2017. It is a type of visual novel game that features alternate endings and revolves around the theme of parallel universes. The game is set in Tokyo and is about another video game. It was developed by Red Entertainment and was written by Taro Achi. The game was released on November 9, 2017, and is available on multiple computing platforms, including PlayStation Vita, PlayStation 4, Microsoft Windows, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch. It also carries alternative titles such as "Oretachi no Sekai wa Owatteiru" and "Judgement 7 - Our World is Ended".
data.rationale: "Our World is Ended" fits the definition of a "2017 video game" as it is a digital game that was first released to the public in the calendar year 2017, specifically on November 9, 2017. It involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback, as it is a type of visual novel game. The game is available on multiple platforms, including consoles and personal computers, which aligns with the definition's mention of various platforms. The term "2017 video game" does not denote any particular style, quality, or technological advancement, and "Our World is Ended" does not need to meet any such criteria to fit the definition. Therefore, based on the provided definition, "Our World is Ended" can be classified as a "2017 video game".

data.label: Final Fantasy XV
data.description: Final Fantasy XV is an action role-playing video game that is part of the Final Fantasy video game series. Released in 2016 for platforms such as PlayStation 4, PlayStation 3, Xbox One, Microsoft Windows, and Google Stadia, the game was developed and published by Square Enix. The game is set on fictional planets and is noted for being in development hell. The game's score was composed by Yoko Shimomura and supports cross-platform play. It is known for being a best-selling PlayStation 4 video game that also supports Steam Workshop. The game was directed by Hajime Tabata, produced by Shinji Hashimoto, and features artwork by Yusuke Naora, Tetsuya Nomura, and Isamu Kamikokuryo. It is powered by the Luminous Engine. The game also has various alternate titles, including "Final Fantasy XV: Episode Ardyn," "Final Fantasy XV: Episode Ignis," "Final Fantasy XV Royal Edition," and "Final Fantasy XV: Windows Edition," among others.
data.rationale: Based on the provided definition and information, there is no valid argument to assert that Final Fantasy XV is a 2017 video game. The entity description clearly states that Final Fantasy XV was released in 2016, not 2017. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria of a "2017 video game" as defined above.

data.label: Fortnite
data.description:
Fortnite is a highly popular and influential video game developed in the United States. It is a named individual by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) and recognized as a Hasbro toy. Fortnite is a winner of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) award for video games and has also garnered accolades at The Game Awards. It was released in 2017 and quickly became a fad or trend in both the 2010s and 2020s. 

The game is a free-to-play model available on multiple platforms including PlayStation 4, iOS, MacOS, Nintendo Switch, Windows, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X and Series S. It became the highest-grossing mobile game and one of the most played video games globally. Fortnite is known for its online multiplayer feature and its status as a crossover video game, incorporating elements from various franchises. 

It is also notable for its reaction to the George Floyd protests, making changes in response to the civil rights movement. Fortnite is developed with the Unreal Engine and has been associated with different esports teams such as Team Liquid, Misfits Gaming, and G2 Esports. It has been referenced and incorporated in various aspects of popular culture, including being a product of Moose Toys and Epic Games.
data.rationale: The entity Fortnite fits the definition of a "2017 video game" as it was first released and made available to the public in the calendar year 2017. This is explicitly stated in the description of Fortnite. Furthermore, Fortnite is a digital or electronic game that involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on two- or three-dimensional video display devices, which aligns with the definition of a video game. The game is available on multiple platforms such as consoles, personal computers, and mobile devices, which is also a characteristic of a 2017 video game as per the definition. Therefore, based on the provided definition and the information about Fortnite, it can be argued that Fortnite is a 2017 video game.

data.label: Hiveswap
data.description: "Hiveswap" is an episodic video game set on fictional planets, released in 2017. It is heavily influenced by webcomics and contains LGBT characters as part of its narrative. The game, which is part of the Homestuck series, was developed in the United States and funded through Kickstarter. It operates on various computing platforms, including MacOS, Microsoft Windows, and Linux, and utilizes the Unity game engine. Toby Fox, known for his work on the game "Undertale", scored the music for Hiveswap. Andrew Hussie, the creator of the Homestuck webcomic, is both the writer and producer for the game. Despite being highly anticipated, Hiveswap has been criticized for its long development time, leading some to label it as "vaporware".
data.rationale: Hiveswap fits the definition of a 2017 video game because it was first released or made available to the public in the calendar year 2017. It is a digital or electronic game that involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on two- or three-dimensional video display devices. The game operates on various computing platforms, including MacOS, Microsoft Windows, and Linux, which aligns with the definition's mention of multiple platforms such as consoles, personal computers, or mobile devices. The term "2017 video game" does not denote any particular style, quality, or technological advancement, and Hiveswap does not need to meet any specific criteria in these areas to be classified as such. Therefore, based on the information provided, Hiveswap can be considered a 2017 video game.

data.label: Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus
data.description: "Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" is a dystopian video game developed by MachineGames and published by Bethesda Softworks. The game, which can be played on PlayStation 4, Microsoft Windows, Nintendo Switch, and Xbox One, falls under the genre of first-person shooter, action game, and action-adventure game. The game features an alternate history fiction set in 1961 and includes various locations such as Venus, New Mexico, Texas, Alaska, Chicago, Kansas, New Orleans, New York City, and Washington, D.C. The game is part of the Wolfenstein series and is a sequel with downloadable content. It was released on October 27, 2017, and June 29, 2018. The game has been the subject of advertising and marketing controversy and includes the cultural depiction of Adolf Hitler. The game is also known as "Wolfenstein II", "The New Colossus", "Wolfenstein 2: The New Colossus", and "II: The New Colossus". The game's score was composed by Martin Stig Andersen and Mick Gordon. The game was developed using the Id Tech 6 engine and has been recognized as a winner at The Game Awards.
data.rationale: "Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" fits the definition of a "2017 video game" because it was first released to the public on October 27, 2017, which falls within the calendar year 2017. The game involves interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on video display devices, which is a characteristic of video games as defined. It belongs to the genres of first-person shooter, action game, and action-adventure game, which are included in the wide range of genres that video games can belong to. Therefore, based on the provided definition and the information about the entity, "Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus" can be classified as a "2017 video game".

It is an open-world game with stealth, action-adventure, simulation, puzzle, and sports gameplay elements. Other key aspects include its use of Nvidia 3D Vision, PhysX, and stereoscopic 3D graphics. Its narrative, written by Paul Dini, involves Batman being sealed in a section of the city and features alternative versions and additional content.
